awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing (AM), often referred to as 3D printing, is a manufacturing process for producing complex structures that either could not be otherwise achieved or which could only be achieved with significant waste using traditional subtractive manufacturing processes. Additive manufacturing is widespread in its applications and impacts industries such as automotive, aerospace, medical products, and defense. One common form of AM is fused filament fabrication (FFF) in which molten material is extruded and patterned layer-by-layer to form a part. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project investigates new FFF processes using sensors and modeling to observe, characterize, and control the molten materials as they are being processed. This will be done in collaboration with industry partner Stratasys, a world leader in AM technologies, to assist in the machinery and materials research.  The research will broadly impact US competitiveness and environmental conservation by enabling products to be more rapidly and consistently produced than is possible today with current AM or alternative manufacturing processes. The successful implementation of this project will support American innovation and ingenuity by enabling the 3D printing of new materials, increasing the manufacturing throughput and quality of 3D printed products, and providing continuous quality assurance for manufactured products. 

This research will investigate the fundamental linkages between polymer rheology and resulting part properties in FFF by testing two hypotheses: 1) Melt viscosity can be accurately determined based on the upstream motor torque and speed, and; 2) The extent of polymer diffusion across the filament's weld can be predicted knowing the melt viscosity. Testing these hypotheses necessitates an understanding of polymer rheological behavior under the non-isothermal, non-steady state conditions of the FFF process, as well as how the rheological behavior affects physical and mechanical properties of a printed structure. There are three major research tasks in this project: 1. On-line modeling of the polymer viscosity using the FFF as a capillary rheometer; 2. FFF modeling (including part property predictions) and adaptive, model-based control of the filament extrusion, welding, and solidification; 3. Validation using an advanced experimental platform that includes a closed loop stepper motor as well as an instrumented nozzle. The fundamental impact of this work lies in the modeling of processing-structure-property relationships using real-time feedback provided by advanced process instrumentation. The research is thus expected to provide guidance for processing a wider range of polymers based on their inherent non-isothermal, shear thinning behavior. Moreover, by considering the relationship between the viscosity and underlying molecular morphology, this research will also provide guidance in how to develop new materials for FFF. The translation of project results to commercially relevant products/systems is greatly increased through the participation of the GOALI partner Stratasys and its employees. A more capable and informed workforce in this important area is ensured through the participation of graduate and undergraduate students in the research as well as the NSF-funded center for additive manufacturing, SHAP3D.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This project advanced 3D printing, specifically material extrusion additive manufacturing (MatEx), also known as fused filament fabrication (FFF). FFF can create complex, custom parts at low cost but can struggle in achieving high-quality, strong, and durable parts. So, we investigated new tools, models, and techniques to better understand and control the 3D printing process, making it more capable and sustainable. Our work was divided into two main areas: extrusion modeling and control and deposition modeling and control.

Intellectual Merit: Advancing 3D Printing Technology

  1. Extrusion Modeling and Control
    Led by Dr. David Kazmer, this research focused on two critical aspects of the polymer melt during extrusion: temperature and pressure. We developed detailed models to predict and control the behavior of the polymer as it flows through the nozzle. A major accomplishment was the creation of an instrumented hot end (the heated nozzle used in FFF), which was enhanced with sensors to measure real-time data on temperature, pressure, and flow rate. These measurements were used to create control systems that improve material flow, ensuring that parts are printed uniformly. This capability allows for fine adjustments during printing, leading to parts with better mechanical properties, such as increased strength and consistency. Moreover, we analyzed energy consumption within the extrusion process, identifying ways to improve efficiency while maintaining high quality, which contributes to more sustainable 3D printing practices.
  2. Deposition Modeling and Control
    Led by Dr. Amy Peterson, the deposition research aimed to improve how layers bond to each other during printing. We developed models that predicted how temperature and time influence the bonding of each new layer to the previous one. By applying polymer science theories related to interdiffusion and welding, we predicted mechanical properties like tear strength and tensile strength, which are essential for achieving durable, high-quality parts. These models were validated through experiments, including thermographic analysis and mechanical testing, to ensure they accurately reflected real-world conditions. Our findings showed that parameters like print speed, layer time, and layer contact area are crucial for achieving optimal bonding and reducing defects. These insights make it possible to fine-tune the printing process to produce parts with better durability and strength.

Broader Impacts: Supporting Sustainability, Workforce Development, and Technological Transfer

This project also created substantial societal benefits. Our work promotes sustainable manufacturing practices by reducing energy use, conserving materials, and minimizing waste in 3D printing. Additionally, the findings of this project contribute valuable information for decision-makers in industries such as aerospace, automotive, and biomedical, where manufacturing practices must balance performance, cost, and environmental impact.

1. Sustainability and Efficiency
By developing more efficient and controlled 3D printing methods, our research helps reduce the amount of material used and the energy required, contributing to a smaller environmental footprint. This focus on sustainability aligns with global goals for responsible production and energy conservation. The comparative analysis of 3D printing and traditional injection molding provides valuable guidance on how to choose manufacturing methods that are not only cost-effective but also environmentally conscious.

2. Workforce Development
Two doctoral students were devoted to this project, becoming experts in advanced manufacturing techniques, real-time process monitoring, multi-physics modeling, and process optimization. Additionally, our project findings have been integrated into graduate courses at the University of Massachusetts Lowell, exposing several cohorts of students to cutting-edge research and advanced manufacturing technologies.

3. Technology Transfer
The project has laid the foundation for technology transfer with our GOALI (Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry) partner, Stratasys, a global leader in 3D printing technology. Stratasys is currently evaluating our compressibility control algorithms and the instrumented hot end for potential commercialization. These technologies could enhance Stratasys’s product offerings by improving process control and expanding the capabilities of their 3D printers, driving broader adoption of the research findings across industry.

Key Findings and Future Directions

The key findings of this project highlight both scientific and practical advancements. Our models and control strategies enable more precise tracking and control of temperature, pressure, and material flow during 3D printing. This results in parts with higher strength, better durability, and reduced defects, which is critical for the widespread adoption of 3D printing in high-performance applications. Additionally, the project’s advancements in thermal modeling provide a framework for further integrating edge computing and artificial intelligence in manufacturing. This integration will allow for real-time decision-making, predictive control, and optimized resource use, aligning with the future of smart manufacturing.

Going forward, these findings provide a foundation for continued innovation in 3D printing and additive manufacturing. The advanced models, datasets, and techniques developed through this project are valuable resources for researchers, engineers, and manufacturers working to further improve the quality, efficiency, and sustainability of additive manufacturing processes. As these technologies evolve, they hold the potential to revolutionize how industries develop products and sustainable manufacturing systems.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2024
Modified by: David O Kazmer
